#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The Thousand Guilders
#Text=None seeing the humble supper eaten in the Brinker cottage that night would have dreamed of the dainty repast hidden away nearby .
#Text=Hans and Gretel looked rather wistfully toward the cupboard as they drank their cupful of water and ate their scanty share of black bread ; but even in thought they did not rob their father .
#Text=“ He relished his supper well , ” said Dame Brinker , nodding sidewise toward the bed , “ and fell asleep the next moment .
#Text=Ah , the dear man will be feeble for many a day .
#Text=He wanted sore to sit up again , but while I made show of humoring him and getting ready , he dropped off .

#Text=Remember that , my girl , when you have a man of your own ( and many a day may it be before that comes to pass ) , remember that you can never rule by differing ; ‘ humble wife is husband ’s boss . ’ Tut ! tut !
#Text=Never swallow such a mouthful as that again , child .
#Text=Why , I could make a meal off two such pieces .
#Text=What ’s in thee , Hans ?
#Text=One would think there were cobwebs on the walls . ”
#Text=“ Oh , no , Mother , I was only thinking -- ”
#Text=“ Thinking about what ?
#Text=Ah , no use asking , ” she added in a changed tone .
#Text=“ I was thinking of the same a while ago .
#Text=Well , it ’s no blame if we DID look to hear something by this time about the thousand guilders but not a word -- no -- it ’s plain enough he knows naught about them . ”

#Text=Hans looked up anxiously , dreading lest his mother should grow agitated , as usual , when speaking of the lost money , but she was silently nibbling her bread and looking with a doleful stare toward the window .
#Text=“ Thousand guilders , ” echoed a faint voice from the bed .
#Text=“ Ah , I am sure they have been of good use to you , vrouw , through the long years when your man was idle . ”
#Text=The poor woman started up .
#Text=These words quite destroyed the hope that of late had been glowing within her .
#Text=“ Are you awake , Raff ? ” she faltered .
#Text=“ Yes , Meitje , and I feel much better .
#Text=Our money was well saved , vrouw , I was saying .
#Text=Did it last through all those ten years ? ”
#Text=“ I -- I -- have not got it , Raff , I -- ”
#Text=She was going to tell him the whole truth when Hans lifted his finger warningly and whispered , “ Remember what the meester told us .
#Text=The father must not be worried . ”
#Text=“ Speak to him , child , ” she answered , trembling .
#Text=Hans hurried to the bedside .
#Text=“ I am glad you are feeling better , ” he said , leaning over his father .
#Text=“ Another day will see you quite strong again . ”
#Text=“ Aye , like enough .
#Text=How long did the money last , Hans ? I could not hear your mother .
#Text=What did she say ? ”
#Text=“ I said , Raff , ” stammered Dame Brinker in great distress , “ that it was all gone . ”
#Text=“ Well , well , wife , do not fret at that ; one thousand guilders is not so very much for ten years and with children to bring up ... but it has helped to make you all comfortable .
#Text=Have you had much sickness to bear ? ”
#Text=“ No , no , ” sobbed Dame Brinker , lifting her apron to her eyes .
#Text=“ Tut , tut , woman , why do you cry ? ” said Raff kindly . “ We will soon fill another pouch when I am on my feet again .
#Text=Lucky I told you all about it before I fell . ”
#Text=“ Told me what , man ? ”
#Text=“ Why , that I buried the money .
#Text=In my dream just now , it seemed that I had never said aught about it . ”
#Text=Dame Brinker started forward .
#Text=Hans caught her arm .
#Text=“ Hist ! Mother , ” he whispered , hastily leading her away , “ we must be very careful . ”
#Text=Then , while she stood with clasped hands waiting in breathless anxiety , he once more approached the cot .
#Text=Trembling with eagerness he said , “ That was a troublesome dream .
#Text=Do you remember WHEN you buried the money , Father ? ”
#Text=“ Yes , my boy .
#Text=It was just before daylight on the same day I was hurt .
#Text=Jan Kamphuisen said something , the sundown before , that made me distrust his honesty .
#Text=He was the only one living besides Mother who knew that we had saved a thousand guilders , so I rose up that night and buried the money -- blockhead that I was ever to suspect an old friend ! ”
#Text=“ I ’ll be bound , Father , ” pursued Hans in a laughing voice , motioning to his mother and Gretel to remain quiet , “ that you ’ve forgotten where you buried it . ”
#Text=“ Ha ! ha ! Not I , indeed .
#Text=But good night , my son , I can sleep again . ”
#Text=Hans would have walked away , but his mother ’s gestures were not to be disobeyed .
#Text=So he said gently , “ Good night , Father .
#Text=Where did you say you buried the money ?
#Text=I was only a little one then . ”
#Text=“ Close by the willow sapling behind the cottage , ” said Raff Brinker drowsily .
#Text=“ Ah , yes .
#Text=North side of the tree , was n’t it , Father ? ”
#Text=“ No , the south side .
#Text=Ah , you know the spot well enough , you rogue .
#Text=Like enough you were there when your mother lifted it .
#Text=Now , son , easy .
#Text=Shift this pillow so .
#Text=Good night . ”
#Text=“ Good night , Father ! ” said Hans , ready to dance for joy .
#Text=The moon rose very late that night , shining in , full and clear , at the little window , but its beams did not disturb Raff Brinker .
#Text=He slept soundly ; so did Gretel .
#Text=As for Hans and his mother , they had something else to do .

#Text=After making a few hurried preparations , they stole forth with bright , expectant faces , bearing a broken spade and a rusty implement that had done many a day ’s service when Raff was a hale worker on the dikes .
